item.title: Thank you from LDS Charities
item.description: LDS Charities believes we are better together. We would like to thank our donors, partners and volunteers for helping us improve lives around the globe, thank you for all that you do!

item.title: Humanitarian Visitor Center Film
item.description: This video shows some of the humanitarian efforts of the LDS church and how it helps individuals world-wide.

item.title: Refuge from the Storm
item.description: Tens of millions of people have been displaced from their homes due to conflict and famine—half of these individuals are children. Elder Patrick Kearon speaks about the Savior’s experience as a refugee, and how we can follow His example to be models of love and compassion refugees and strangers among us. For more information about how you can get involved with refugee efforts in your community, visit: IWasAStranger.lds.org.

item.title: "I knew we were probably losing everything" South Carolina Flooding 2015 - Give Back by the Mormon Channel
item.description: When a flood hit Columbia South Carolina, local members were quick to respond to the needs of the flood victims.

item.title: Emergency Response Volunteer Training
item.description: Wards and stakes may organize volunteers to assist in the community following a disaster. All volunteers should adhere to Church safety guidelines for disaster cleanup.

item.title: Kurdistan—Erbil House
item.description: LDS Charities partners with local organizations in Erbil, Kurdistan, to help refugee families in need by providing food, supplies, and shelter.

item.title: Sierra Leone—Civil War Response
item.description: LDS members come to the aid of victims of the Sierra Leone Civil War.

item.title: Kurdistan—Refugee Response
item.description: LDS Charities gives assistance to a refugee camp in Kurdistan.

item.title: Philippines Typhoon—Emergency Response
item.description: LDS Charities teaches carpentry skills to typhoon victims so they can build homes for other victims.

item.title: Chile—Earthquake Emergency Response
item.description: LDS Charities provides much-needed supplies and shelter after the 2010 Chile earthquake.

item.title: Philippines Hurricane Welfare Response
item.description: The 2013 typhoon in the Philippines affected millions of people. LDS Charities and local Church leaders helped members as they began rebuilding their lives.

item.title: LDS Charities Syrian Response 2013
item.description: A short video outlining the the church's humanitarian response to the early days of the Syrian refugee crisis.

item.title: We Did Not Stand Alone
item.description: War in Sierra Leone disrupted people's lives so that many could not even get food to eat. The Church provided food, hygiene kits, clothing, and blankets to help the people.

item.title: Chile Priesthood Response
item.description: Following a massive earthquake that struck Santiago, Chile, in February 2010, LDS Charities and local Church members helped people all throughout the city to obtain food, water, and shelter.

item.title: Samoa Tsunami Relief Effort
item.description: Church members were ready to help the victims of a tsunami that destroyed villages in Samoa. Food, supplies, and donated labor were provided to help rebuild homes.

item.title: Haiti Emergency Response
item.description: After the earthquake in Haiti, members of the Church organized humanitarian efforts to assist those in need. The local meetinghouses were offered as medical and living areas.

item.title: Chile Earthquake YSA Service
item.description: Young single adults attending institute in Santiago gather to prepare hygiene kits for victims of the earthquake.

item.title: Syrian Refugee—Emergency Response
item.description: LDS Charities partnered with local charity organizations in Jordan to provide Syrian refugees with lifesaving supplies.

item.title: Sierra Leone—Building Wheelchairs
item.description: LDS Charities partners with local organizations to donate wheelchairs to those in need and also to teach local people how to build their own wheelchairs that can be donated to more remote locations in Sierra Leone.

item.title: Riqui's Wheelchair
item.description: Although polio took away the use of his legs when he was young, Riqui has not let this disability stop him. Riqui's new wheelchair helps him in his effort to live a full life.

item.title: Sierra Leone Wheelchairs
item.description: Since 2001, the Church has distributed more than 350,000 wheelchairs to countries all over the world.

item.title: Dominican Republic—Wheelchair Initiative
item.description: The LDS Charities wheelchair program increased the standard of living for Dominicans who were immobile due to various disabilities.

item.title: Dominican Republic—Boys’ Home
item.description: LDS Charities assists a boys’ home with clothes and toys.

item.title: Dominican Republic—Prosthetics
item.description: LDS Charities assists a prosthetic clinic in helping dozens of people in the Dominican Republic obtain prosthetic limbs to improve their quality of life.

item.title: Romania—Homeless Clinic
item.description: LDS Charities assists a homeless medical clinic in Bucharest, Romania, with much-needed resources.

item.title: Quilts
item.description: The Church donates necessary commodities like hygiene kits, medical supplies, clothing, and quilts to people in need all over the world.

item.title: Mayerlinth’s Mobility
item.description: A young woman receives a set of prosthetic legs that enable her to walk again after being struck by a vehicle over 10 years ago.

item.title: Boys' Home
item.description: LDS Charities partners with Food for the Poor to deliver food, clothing, and toys to children in the Dominican Republic.

item.title: The USNS Comfort
item.description: Volunteer members of the Church work as nurses, administrators, and translators on the U.S. Navy ship to provide medical needs in Latin America.

item.title: Bolivia Humanitarian Impact
item.description: The Church created lasting friendships with government officials in Bolivia through humanitarian efforts.

item.title: Bolivia Hospital Restoration
item.description: Los Andes Maternal Hospital, the only health institution to help mothers and newborns in La Paz, Bolivia, had fallen into disrepair. Every weekend for a considerable time members worked to make needed repairs.

item.title: Romania—AIDS Hospital Partnership
item.description: LDS Charities partners with an AIDS recovery hospital in Bucharest, Romania to improve patient care.

item.title: A Child's First Breath
item.description: Neonatal resuscitation training is one of many humanitarian efforts that fall under the curtain of the Church welfare program.

item.title: Neonatal Resuscitation Training – Africa
item.description: Neonatal training is provided to local community nurses and doctors to improve infant mortality rates.

item.title: Dominican Republic—Neonatal Resuscitation Training
item.description: LDS Charities trained doctors and nurses in the Dominican Republic in newborn resuscitation to help decrease the infant mortality rate.

item.title: Sierra Leone—Clean Water
item.description: LDS Charities partners with a Sierra Leone village to dig wells and provide clean water to hundreds of people who did not have access before.

item.title: A Thousand Days
item.description: By digging wells and boreholes in drought-stricken countries of Africa, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints helps provide health and happiness to entire villages.

item.title: Clean Water Is Happiness
item.description: By digging wells and boreholes in drought-stricken countries of Africa, The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints helps provide health and happiness to entire villages.

item.title: Democratic Republic of Congo—Clean Water Project
item.description: LDS Charities partnered with a community in the Democratic Republic of Congo to help them pipe clean water to their city for the first time.

item.title: Haiti—Raising Chickens
item.description: LDS Charities partners with local leaders to teach families how to raise chickens to provide food and work for families in need—while also helping them become more self-sufficient.

item.title: Navajo Reservation—Garden Project
item.description: LDS Charities partners with local leaders to teach families how to garden and become more self-sufficient.

item.title: Democratic Republic of Congo—Cassava Food Project
item.description: LDS Charities helps the people of the DR Congo plant a new breed of cassava that grows much faster.

item.title: Bolivia—Underground Greenhouse Project
item.description: LDS Charities teaches people in Bolivia how to build and cultivate their very own underground greenhouse.

item.title: Bolivia—Container Garden Project
item.description: LDS Charities provides training and supplies for families in Bolivia to grow vegetables, improving their health and overall quality of life.

item.title: Seeking Inspiration to Build Self-Reliance
item.description: Members of a small branch in the Philippines seek inspiration to build self-reliance and strengthen individuals and families in their area.

item.title: A Desolate Land Blossoms
item.description: With the help of LDS Charities and welfare service missionaries, local priesthood leaders among the Navajo and Hopi peoples are teaching principles of self-reliance and provident living through gardening.

item.title: Cassava Fields
item.description: For members living in the Democratic Republic of Congo, the Church has provided training on growing cassava and processing flour.

item.title: Ecuador Food Production
item.description: The Benson Institute of the Church Welfare Department helps people in impoverished rural areas of third-world countries. It teaches about improving agricultural practices, raising small animals, and practicing good nutrition and basic hygiene.

item.title: Bolivia Container Gardens
item.description: A woman’s health is improved as she learns how to grow vegetables in a container garden.

item.title: Bolivia Underground Greenhouses
item.description: Because of the high altitude and cold climate, it is difficult for the people of the Andes to grow vegetables. With the help of the Church, families are able to grow vegetables in subterranean greenhouses.

item.title: Ecuador—Benson Food
item.description: Volunteers with the LDS Charities Benson Food Initiative taught villagers in Ecuador how to grow and prepare nutritious foods.

item.title: World of Happiness
item.description: The Church donated materials and equipment to improve vision in Peru.

item.title: Peru—Vision Care Project
item.description: LDS Charities partnered with local clinics and schools to bring vision care to the people of Puno, Peru.

item.title: Teaching English to Refugees
item.description: When looking for service opportunities, Kerry Porter discovered that she could use her few spare hours during the week to teach English at a local refugee center.

item.title: “I Call Her My Church Mommy.” How mentors benefit refugees—Give Back by the Mormon Channel
item.description: When Chantal and her family were relocated from Africa to the United States, they felt a culture shock. What made the most difference for Chantal was having adults who were willing to be mentors for her.

item.title: Welcome to America: Giving Refugees New Hope with Household Goods
item.description: The Welcome to America project is a nonprofit in Phoenix that brings donated goods to refugees’ homes and helps them start their new lives.

item.title: Scout Troop Learns that Helping Refugees is as Easy as Riding a Bike - Give Back By Mormon Channel
item.description: A local Boy Scout troop teamed up with the IRC to build bikes for refugees in need of better transportation. It turned out to be a bonding experience that the boys would never forget.

item.title: Refugee Baby Shower: Giving One Family a New Start – Give Back by Mormon Channel
item.description: A relief society decides to heed the call from the first presidency to help refugees by throwing a refugee mother a baby shower.

item.title: Teaching Self-Reliance in Haiti
item.description: The people of Haiti endure unemployment, sickness, hunger, and more. Some have found hope, however, thanks to a special project that gives them the means to live happier, healthier lives.

item.title: Rebuilding Lives after Typhoon Yolanda
item.description: In 2013, the Philippines were devastated by the strongest typhoon ever recorded. The surge of service, love, and hope that followed, however, was even stronger.

item.title: Be a Sincere Friend
item.description: Fatou, a refugee from Ivory Coast, and Toni share a love for cross-country running and develop a friendship far beyond the Big Brothers Big Sisters program.

item.title: Reward and Motivate Academic Success
item.description: Children at a local elementary school are able to earn roadrunner tickets for good behavior and academics. They are then able to use those tickets to purchase items from an incentive store once a month.

item.title: I Was a Stranger—Invite a Refugee to Dinner
item.description: Milan and her daughters are refugees from Bhutan. Michelle and her family meet them and invite them over to cook dinner together and learn about each other’s culture.

item.title: Feeding the Refugees in Beirut
item.description: When Antoinette was a young girl, her parents taught her to take care of those in need by giving them food and a place to stay. Her father told her that some day she should open a free restaurant for the hungry.

item.title: Providing for the Refugees in Lebanon
item.description: Refugees who fled from violence in Syria to peace in Lebanon are still facing serious challenges. There are no jobs for the adults and no schools for the children. Many are going without daily necessities.

item.title: Giving All for Refugees in Kurdistan
item.description: Dr. Nemam is a native of Kurdistan, a land torn apart by war. She was working in Sweden when she heard news that her people were suffering, so she decided to return and offer any help she could.

item.title: Rescuing Refugees in Kurdistan
item.description: Refugees from Mosul in Northern Iraq were given a place to live when two brothers gave up their houses to 23 families.

item.title: Always Something to Give – The Coconut Farmer
item.description: In November 2013, the strongest typhoon ever recorded slammed into the Philippines. The opportunities to help each other along created a beautiful silver lining around an otherwise terrible tragedy.

item.title: Serving the Community - Immunization Awareness
item.description: Providing so many people with vaccinations for deadly diseases like measles seems like an impossible task. That doesn’t stop Gaylene from doing her part in her community.

item.title: Helping Refugees in Iraq – The Mayor of Howesk
item.description: “We are not perfect, but we love helping others, because we know this is an emergency, and people in hard situations should show who they really are and be good to one another,” says the mayor.

item.title: Making a Difference to Orphans with HIV
item.description: Orphans is Romania received blood transfusions in the 1980s to make them stronger—but the blood was actually infected with HIV. Through the use of a single syringe, the virus was passed along from one child to another.

item.title: War in Sierra Leone – Saved from the Rebels
item.description: War devastated Sierra Leone for over 10 years. Rebels were killing civilians, civilians who weren’t killed had no food, and the road to freedom was blocked. Survivors Abie and Mohammad Turay are proof that God lives and loves His children.

item.title: Saving Children – Measles Vaccination
item.description: When she lost her baby boy to a preventable disease, Helen knew she had to do something to save others from similar tragedy.

item.title: Aids Clinic – Fighting for Others
item.description: In the 1980s, countless Romanian orphans were infected with the HIV virus through blood transfusions, vaccinations, and immunizations in hospitals. Dan was one of those orphans. Now a grown man, he was the only survivor among his friends.

item.title: 30 Million People Need Prosthetic Limbs
item.description: Her life changed at 15 years of age when—in front of her home in Santa Domingo—a car lost control and accidentally ran her over. This tragic car accident left Mayerlinth Reyes with a completely different state of life.

item.title: Helping Babies Breathe
item.description: A story of service involving reviving babies at birth.

item.title: Bolivia Greenhouses
item.description: A story of service at a greenhouse project in Bolivia

item.title: Water for Laputa
item.description: LDS Charities helps a town in the DR Congo get clean water. Men from the village dug a trench by hand to bring the water from the mountain to the people. It took them 1,000 days.

item.title: Water Well in Sierra Leone
item.description: Sierra Leone is in the midst of a water crisis. Listen to this Sierra Leonean woman tell her story of water crisis and how the people in her village were able to build a well and receive clean, healthy water.

item.title: Service in Ethiopia
item.description: One woman shares how she is giving back in her refugee community in Ethiopia.

item.title: Smiling Faces In Sierra Leone - Donating Wheelchairs
item.description: Malaga Bundor of Sierra Leone, has spent his life with Spina Bifida. Given the skills to build his own wheelchair and wheelchairs for others you can’t help but see how proud it makes him feel.

item.title: Syrian Refugee - “The moment I was shot I knew I would never walk again”
item.description: With millions impacted by the Syrian civil war that broke out in 2011, many have fled for safety and refuge. Watch and listen to Nadia’s story; a 12-year-old Syrian refugee child, who while fleeing Syria, was shot in the back and paralyzed.

item.title: Kingsley Mamabolo—South Africa Ambassador to the United Nations
item.description: Kingsley Mamabolo talks about the relationship between South Africa and LDS Charities.

item.title: Leslie Goldman—U.S. Fund for UNICEF
item.description: Leslie Goldman talks about the relationship between the U.S. Fund for UNICEF and LDS Charities.

item.title: Libran Nuevas Cabactulan—Philippines Ambassador to the United Nations
item.description: Libran Nuevas Cabactulan talks about the relationship between the Philippines and LDS Charities.

item.title: Simona-Mirela Miculescu: Representative of Romania to the United Nations
item.description: Simona-Mirela Miculescu, the permanent representative of Romania to the United Nations, shares her thoughts on the country’s partnership with LDS Charities.

item.title: Dr. Nemam Ghafouri—Swedish Specialist Hospital
item.description: Dr. Nemam talks about the assistance given to Bajed Kandala Camp 2 by LDS Charities.

item.title: Gail McGovern Thank You Message—American Red Cross
item.description: Gail McGovern says thank you for the donation given to the Red Cross by the LDS Church from the proceeds of Meet the Mormons.

item.title: Father Paul Karam—Caritas Lebanon
item.description: Father Paul Karam talks about the partnership between LDS Charities and Caritas Lebanon.

item.title: Dr. Gullapalli Rao—L V Prasad Eye Institute
item.description: Dr. Rao talks about the partnership between LDS Charities and the Prasad Eye Institute.

item.title: Janet Garin: Minister of the Department of Health, Philippines
item.description: Janet Garin talks about her recent partnership with LDS Charities on a nationwide immunization campaign in the Philippines.

item.title: Baroness Emma Nicholson: AMAR Foundation
item.description: Baroness Emma Nicholson talks about the partnership between AMAR and LDS Charities.

item.title: Andrea Gay – The United Nations Foundation
item.description: Andrea Gay of the United Nations Foundation describes the help LDS Charities provides in running immunization campaigns.

item.title: Mary Veal – Hope For Health
item.description: Hope for Health founder Mary Veal describes LDS Charities donations, such as blankets and baby clothes, that have fulfilled many of their hospital’s needs.

item.title: Gail McGovern on Volunteers – American Red Cross
item.description: Gail McGovern, American Red Cross president, explains how LDS Charities quickly supplies willing volunteers for disaster response

item.title: Gail McGovern on Immunizations – American Red Cross
item.description: American Red Cross president Gail McGovern talks about the valuable volunteer and financial support of LDS Charities during recent African measles immunization campaigns.

item.title: Mustapha Turray – Sierra Leone Clean Water Project Manager
item.description: Mustapha Turray, Sierra Leone clean water project manager, describes the benefits of the LDS Charities well projects.

item.title: Mussa Mansaray – Sierra Leone Bo Government Hospital
item.description: Mussa Mansaray, head of rehabilitation services at the Sierra Leone Bo Government Hospital, discusses the LDS Charities wheelchair project.

item.title: Jamal Iqtish – Islamic Relief
item.description: Jamal Iqtish of Islamic Relief explains how LDS Charities has donated clothing, blankets, and hygiene supplies to Syrian refugees.

item.title: Mohammad Nasser Kilani – Jordan Hashemite Charity Organization
item.description: Mohammad Nasser Kilani of the Jordan Hashemite Charity Organization describes how LDS Charities provides relief supplies to help refugees and others in need.

item.title: Igor Samac – International Relief and Development
item.description: Igor Samac, senior program officer at International Relief and Development, describes how LDS Charities allows their organization to respond to disasters more quickly.

item.title: Richard Wagner – International Relief and Development
item.description: Richard Wagner, senior program officer at International Relief and Development, describes their long-term partnership with LDS Charities.

item.title: Anwar Khan – Islamic Relief
item.description: CEO of Islamic Relief Anwar Khan describes their partnership with LDS Charities and the two organizations’ shared vision of helping those in need.

item.title: Trevor Riggen – American Red Cross
item.description: Trevor Riggen, vice president of American Red Cross Disaster Operations, describes how LDS Charities has been a long-term, valued partner.

item.title: Jim Lanning – International Relief and Development
item.description: Jim Lanning of International Relief and Development describes how LDS Charities responds to requests for help with efficient, high-quality aid.

item.title: Chris Skopec – International Medical Corps
item.description: Chris Skopec, director of International Operations at International Medical Corps, describes LDS Charities as a true humanitarian organization and the first one they call because of LDS Charities’ ability to quickly mobilize.

item.title: Philippines—Immunization Campaign
item.description: LDS Charities partnered with the Philippines government in a nationwide immunization campaign.
